bestBHT.bht: In this account, the people were so driven by their worldly interests that they pleaded with Jesus to depart from their region, disregarding His miraculous healing. They prioritized material possessions over their spiritual well-being. Their fear of His power and preference for business affairs caused them to reject the Son of God and the Savior of the world. Sadly, their twisted view of Christ reveals a preference for sinful desires over surrendering to Him.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: And they began to pray him to depart out of their coasts—Was it the owners only of the valuable property now lost to them that did this? Alas, no!
The evil spirits had thus, alas! their object. Irritated, the people could not suffer His presence; yet awe-struck, they dared not order Him off.
So they entreat Him to withdraw, and—He takes them at their word.
Philip Schaff: Mark 5:17. To depart out of their borders. See on Matthew 8:34. That Evangelist omits all the incidents of Mark 5:15-16; Mark 5:18-20.
Archibald T. Robertson: Here in Decapolis pagan influence was strong and the owners of the hogs cared more for the loss of their property than for the healing of the wild demoniac.
In the clash between business and spiritual welfare business came first with them as often today.
They feared the power of Jesus and wanted no further interference with their business affairs.
John Gill: They knew not how great a person they had among them; that he was the Son of God, and Saviour of the world.
Such very contrary notions have carnal men of Christ; they are afraid of being sufferers, or losers by him.
They do not care to part with their swinish lusts for him; these they prefer to a Saviour, and love the world, and the things of it, more than he, and therefore are not worthy of him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The people in Mark 5:17, influenced by pagan beliefs and driven by their worldly interests, pleaded with Jesus to leave their region. They prioritized their material possessions over the miraculous healing done by Jesus. They feared His power and were unwilling to make any sacrifices for the sake of their spiritual welfare. Sadly, they failed to realize that they were rejecting the Son of God and the Savior of the world. Such carnal minds have a twisted view of Christ, choosing to hold onto their sinful desires rather than surrendering to Him.

Driven by their worldly interests, the people in this passage requested that Jesus depart from their region, prioritizing their material possessions over His miraculous healing. Fueled by fear of His power, they refused to make sacrifices for their spiritual well-being. They failed to recognize that they were rejecting the Son of God and the Savior of the world, favoring their sinful desires over Him. Such twisted views of Christ demonstrate a preference for worldly pursuits rather than surrendering to Him.

In this account, the people were so driven by their worldly interests that they pleaded with Jesus to depart from their region, disregarding His miraculous healing. They prioritized material possessions over their spiritual well-being. Their fear of His power and preference for business affairs caused them to reject the Son of God and the Savior of the world. Sadly, their twisted view of Christ reveals a preference for sinful desires over surrendering to Him.

Driven by their worldly interests, the people in Mark 5:17 entreated Jesus to depart from their region, prioritizing their material possessions over His miraculous healing. Fueled by their fear of His power and influenced by pagan beliefs, they preferred their business affairs over the presence of the Son of God and the Savior of the world. This rejection shows a twisted view of Christ, as they clung to their sinful desires rather than surrendering to Him.

The people, driven by worldly interests, pleaded for Jesus to depart from their region. They prioritized their material possessions over His healing and feared His power. Their refusal to part with their sinful desires and preference for business affairs caused them to reject the Son of God. Such twisted views of Christ showcase a preference for the world and its pleasures, rather than surrendering to Him.
